description:
Mugil cephalus, commonly known as the flathead mullet or striped mullet, is a species of mullet found in coastal waters around the world, particularly in tropical and subtropical regions. It is a member of the family Mugilidae, which comprises a group of bony fish known for their ability to feed on a variety of organic matter.

Mugil cephalus is a medium-sized fish, typically reaching lengths of 30-60 cm. It has a distinctive flattened head, which gives the species its common name. The body is elongated and streamlined, with a silvery-grey coloration that may feature dark horizontal stripes along the sides.

This species is an omnivorous feeder, consuming a diverse diet that includes algae, detritus, and small invertebrates. Mugil cephalus plays an important ecological role in coastal ecosystems, helping to recycle nutrients and maintain the balance of primary producers.

Mugil cephalus is of significant commercial and recreational importance, as it is widely fished for its edible flesh and valuable roe (eggs). It is cultivated in aquaculture operations in many parts of the world, contributing to global food production.
